properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant winter storm expected Friday into Saturday. Locations: northeastern Newfoundland and the Burin Peninsula. Total snowfall: 15 to 30 cm with locally higher amounts possible. Maximum wind gusts: northerly 90 to 110 km/h inland, with gusts to 120 to 130 km/h along exposed areas of the coast. Storm surge: Higher than normal water levels along the east and northeast coasts due to 60 to 80 cm of storm surge combined with 7 to 10 m waves. Flooding and damage to coastal infrastructure is possible, especially in communities exposed to the north. Highest water levels are expected near high tide Friday night and early Saturday afternoon. Time span: Friday morning until Saturday morning. Remarks: An intense storm will affect the island through the day Friday into Saturday. Anyone planning travel or other weather-sensitive activities is urged to monitor forecasts and to consider alternate plans. Visibility is expected to be reduced to near zero over some areas, with blizzard conditions possible. Conditions are expected to improve early on Saturday for some areas but strong winds, snow and blowing snow will persist over coastal areas in the northeast until midday. ### Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-01-16T11:24:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-15T19:25:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3945300962.2020
Area: Burin Peninsula, Bay of Exploits, Bonavista North, Clarenville and vicinity, Gander and vicinity, Terra Nova
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Accumulating snowfall beginning on Thursday. Total snowfall: 5 to 10 cm with possibility of greater than 15 cm. Locations: southwestern Nova Scotia. Remarks: An intensifying low pressure system approaching from New England will move to lie near southwestern Nova Scotia on Thursday and will skirt the Atlantic Coast before heading away on Friday. This will give snowfall to most of the province. Current guidance suggest the highest amounts may be over southwestern mainland Nova Scotia with the possibility of up to 15 cm of snowfall. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-16T06:37:19-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-15T14:38:19-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4218074302.2020
Area: Digby County, Lunenburg County, Queens County, Shelburne County, Yarmouth County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: 10 to 15 cm of snow possible tonight into Thursday morning. Snow will move into eastern Ontario this evening in association with a low pressure system that is forecast to track across the lower Great Lakes. Latest analysis indicates that 10 to 15 cm will be possible by the time the snow tapers off Thursday morning, with the highest amounts expected near the St. Lawrence River. Motorists are urged to exercise caution, particularly overnight into Thursday morning. Snowfall warnings are not anticipated, as amounts are not expected to surpass the warning criterion of 15 cm within 12 hours. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-16T07:37:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-15T15:38:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3453374252.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An area of low pressure currently offshore will approach the BC Coast late this afternoon. The low will bring strong southeasterly winds to the region. This will create a slow transition from snow to rain for areas mainly near the Strait of Georgia and low lying areas tonight. However, cold air will remain in place over the North Shore, Coquitlam, Pitt Meadows, Maple Ridge, as well as northern sections of Langley and Surrey. Snowfall accumulations of 10 cm is expected over these areas tonight as a result. The snow will ease to scattered showers or flurries Thursday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-16T10:47:39-00:00

Area: Metro Vancouver - North Shore including West Vancouver and North Vancouver, Metro Vancouver - northeast including Coquitlam and Maple Ridge, Metro Vancouver - southeast including Surrey and Langley
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds with higher than normal water levels. Maximum wind gusts: possibly exceeding 90 km/h. Storm surge: higher than normal water levels. Locations: the southeastern Gulf of St. Lawrence and Cape Breton Island. Time span: Thursday night into Friday. Remarks: An intensifying low pressure system approaching from New England will move to lie near southwestern Nova Scotia on Thursday and will track south of Nova Scotia on Friday. High waves and storm surge may affect the southern Gulf of St. Lawrence and Cape Breton Island on Thursday night into Friday. This may cause some minor coastal flooding and overwash on north to northeast facing shorelines of the eastern mainland and Cape Breton during the high tides Thursday night and Friday. Strong northerlies possibly exceeding 90 km/h are possible on Friday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-16T05:15:46-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-15T13:16:46-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3796142180.2020
Area: Antigonish County, Inverness County - south of Mabou, Inverness County - Mabou and north, Victoria County, Sydney Metro and Cape Breton County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of very cold wind chills continues. A bitterly cold arctic ridge of high pressure will remain entrenched over the Yukon. Occasional light winds will give wind chill values below minus 50. The ridge will start to weaken somewhat today with clouds moving in from the west. Regions east of Whitehorse will remain extreme cold under clear skies until Thursday. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-16T04:17:17-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow over Extreme Southern Quebec. Snow will begin early overnight tonight and intensify early Thursday morning. Over the Montérégie area and the Eastern Townships near the American Border, snowfall amounts could reach 10 to 15 centimetres of snow by Thursday evening. Strong northerly winds will develop later Thursday morning and produce blowing snow locally, mainly in exposed areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-16T08:02:11-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant winter storm expected Friday into Saturday. Locations: Avalon and Bonavista Peninsulas. Total snowfall: 30 to 50 cm with 50 to 70 cm possible over parts of the northeast Avalon Peninsula. Maximum wind gusts: northerly 110 to 130 km/h, with gusts to 140 km/h possible along exposed areas of the coast. Storm surge: Higher than normal water levels along the east coast due to 60 to 80 cm of storm surge combined with 7 to 10 m waves. Flooding and damage to coastal infrastructure is possible, especially in communities exposed to the north. Highest water levels are expected near high tide Friday night and early Saturday afternoon. Time span: early Friday morning until Saturday morning. Remarks: An intense storm will affect the island through the day Friday into Saturday. Anyone planning travel or other weather-sensitive activities is urged to monitor forecasts and to consider alternate plans. Visibility is expected to be reduced to near zero over some areas, with blizzard conditions anticipated. Conditions are expected to improve through the morning on Saturday. ### Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-01-16T11:23:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-15T19:24:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3084866118.2020
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest, Bonavista Peninsula
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Extreme cold wind chills of minus 45 tonight. Bitterly cold wind chills of minus 45 or below are forecast to develop tonight and then persist into Thursday morning. While temperatures and wind chills will moderate during the day Thursday, extreme cold wind chills near or below minus 45 are anticipated again Thursday night. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-16T08:17:57-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls and local blowing snow Thursday and Thursday night. Snow squalls are forecast to develop Thursday morning due to cold northwesterly winds in the wake of a weak low pressure system. Up to 15 cm of new snowfall can be expected through Thursday, with an additional 5 to 10 cm possible Thursday night. Blowing snow will accompany the snow squalls at times. The snow squalls are forecast to weaken by early Friday morning. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-16T07:49:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-15T15:50:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0768195199.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds with higher than normal water levels along the north coast. Locations: eastern Prince Edward Island. Maximum wind gusts: possibly reaching 90 km/h. Time span: Thursday night into Friday. Storm surge: higher than normal water levels along parts of the southern Gulf of St. Lawrence on Friday. Remarks: An intensifying low pressure system approaching from New England will move to lie near southwestern Nova Scotia on Thursday and will track south of Nova Scotia on Friday. High waves and storm surge may affect the southern Gulf of St. Lawrence Thursday night into Friday. This combined with a run of spring tides may cause some coastal flooding and overwash on north facing shorelines of the island, especially in the east. The highest risk will be near the high tides Thursday night and Friday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-16T06:36:45-00:00

Area: Kings County P.E.I.
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant storm expected later this week. Locations: central and eastern Newfoundland. Total snowfall: Generally 20 to 40 cm with 40 to 70 cm possible in the vicinity of Trinity or Conception Bay. Maximum wind gusts: 100 to 120 km/h inland. Generally 120 to 130 km/h along the coast with locally higher gusts over exposed areas. Storm surge: higher than normal water levels along the east and northeast coasts due to 60 to 80 cm of storm surge combined with 7 to 10 m waves. Flooding and damage to coastal infrastructure is possible, especially in communities exposed to the north. Highest water levels are expected near high tide on Friday night and again on Saturday morning. Time span: Thursday night until near noon Saturday. Remarks: An intense storm will affect the island later this week. Anyone planning travel or other weather-sensitive activities is urged to monitor forecasts and to begin considering alternate plans. Visibility will likely be reduced to zero over some areas, with blizzard conditions possible. There continues to be a chance that areas of the eastern Avalon Peninsula could see a brief change over to rain on Friday afternoon. There remains some uncertainty regarding the exact track and lowest pressure of this storm. Any variations in track and pressure will affect the above mentioned numbers. Please use this information as a general guide to prepare as the numbers may change before Thursday night. Conditions are expected to improve by early Saturday for some areas but strong winds, snow and blowing snow will persist over coastal areas until mid day. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-01-16T06:22:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-15T14:23:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3865387215.2020

Visibility will likely be poor over some areas, with blizzard conditions possible. properties.Title: Smog Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Atmospheric conditions could result in a deterioration in air quality. High concentrations of pollutants are expected to persist into tonight. ### Smog especially affects asthmatic children and people with respiratory ailments or heart disease. It is therefore recommended that these individuals avoid intense physical activity outdoors until the smog warning is lifted. Additional information: To learn more about the Info-Smog program, go to Environment Canada’s website at www.canada.ca/info-smog-program. For air quality indexes in Quebec, visit the website of the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques at www.iqa.environnement.gouv.qc.ca/contenu/index_en.asp. For the air quality index in Montréal, visit the Réseau de surveillance de la qualité de l’air de la Ville de Montréal’s website at www.rsqa.qc.ca (french only). To learn more about the effects of smog on your health in Québec, visit the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux’s website at www.quebec.ca/en/health. You can also visit the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal at www.santemontreal.qc.ca/en/public. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-01-16T15:24:25-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques, the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux, the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal, the City of Montréal, 2020-01-15T16:11:25-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3275025373.2020

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A multi-day episode of very cold wind chills continues. Bitterly cold arctic air will continue to remain entrenched over the area today. Occasional winds to 15 km/h will give wind chill values down to minus 45. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-16T01:59:49-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-15T16:31:49-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4288739566.2020
Area: Fort Nelson
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 15 cm is expected. Snow from an approaching low pressure system will continue today and will intensify tonight. However, snow near sea level is expected to change to rain this evening as temperatures rise. Additional snow accumulations of 5 to 15 cm can be expected before the snow changes to a few rain showers. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-16T04:56:27-00:00

Area: Malahat Highway - Goldstream to Mill Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snowfall and high winds are expected. 30 cm of snow is forecast to fall today and tonight as a deep low pressure system crosses Vancouver Island. Snow will increase significantly in intensity and southeast winds will rise in excess of 70 km/h tonight. Blowing snow with poor or near zero visibility is expected. Coastal areas will see temperatures rise above freezing overnight tonight and may see precipitation change to rain. However, inland and higher elevations will continue to see heavy snow until Thursday morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-16T05:04:22-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-15T13:05:22-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3404484083.2020
Area: East Vancouver Island - Nanoose Bay to Fanny Bay, East Vancouver Island - Courtenay to Campbell River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Arctic Outflow Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong outflow winds and cold wind chill values are expected or occurring. Cold arctic air will continue to funnel out of the mainland inlets and valleys this morning producing northeast winds of 40 to 60 km/h with gusts as high as 90. The strong winds combined with cold temperatures will generate wind chill values of -20 or lower. Temperatures will gradually rise today and through tonight and reduce the impact of the arctic outflow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-16T05:01:34-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-15T13:02:34-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1118400491.2020
Area: Whistler, Fraser Valley - west including Abbotsford, Fraser Valley - central including Chilliwack, Fraser Valley - east including Hope
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of very cold wind chills is expected. Wind chill values near -40 will continue at times through the day in parts of western Manitoba. This bitterly cold air will expand across southern Manitoba through the day; extreme cold warnings will likely expand eastwards this afternoon. Temperatures are expected to moderate to near-seasonal values for Friday, then colder air returns again for the weekend. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. For more information on cold and your health, visit Manitoba Health at https://www.gov.mb.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/cold.html or call Health Links - Info Santé at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-16T08:32:23-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-15T16:33:23-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2378046648.2020

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A deep low pressure system will cross Vancouver Island Wednesday night. Ahead of the low, southeast winds of 70 to 90 km/h will develop in Greater Victoria early in the evening and spread to the Southern Gulf Islands, East Vancouver Island - Duncan to Nanaimo, southern and western sections of Metro Vancouver and the Sunshine Coast later in the evening. Winds will shift abruptly to the southwest late overnight or Thursday morning in the wake of the low with gusty winds. Winds will ease Thursday morning. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-16T04:51:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-15T12:52:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2477766008.2020

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A snowstorm is expected. A Pacific storm is forecast to bring heavy snow to the West Kootenay region beginning this evening. Snow will continue through Thursday then taper off Thursday night. Total snowfall accumulations of 20 to 30 cm are expected with this event. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 10 cm is expected. A Pacific storm is forecast to bring heavy snow to the southern Fraser Canyon beginning late this afternoon. Snow will taper off to a few flurries overnight. Snowfall amounts of 10 cm are expected by Thursday morning. Strong winds and falling snow will combine to reduce visibility significantly this evening. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-16T10:33:17-00:00

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:

Strong outflow winds and falling snow will combine to significantly reduce visibility over parts of the Fraser Valley and Fraser Canyon. Blowing snow conditions will persist through early Thursday. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Cold arctic air will continue to funnel through Howe Sound producing strong northerly winds of 90 to 110 km/h near Bowen Island today and tonight. In addition, snowfall with total accumulations in excess of 30 cm is expected. The strong arctic outflow winds combined with falling snow will generate blizzard conditions. ### Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-16T10:48:43-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-15T18:49:43-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3924700128.2020

properties.Title: Arctic Outflow Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very strong outflow winds and severely cold wind chill values are expected or occurring. An arctic ridge of high pressure over the BC interior will continue to produce very strong outflow winds, frigid temperatures, and wind chill values of minus 20 and below today. As the ridge weakens, the conditions are expected to gradually improve starting tonight. ### Frostbite and hypothermia can occur within minutes if adequate precautions are not taken when outdoors. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-16T04:20:37-00:00

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Stagnant winter weather conditions are creating elevated pollution levels. (January 15, 2020, 9 am): The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Northern Health has issued an Air Quality Advisory for Prince George and Vanderhoof due to high concentrations of fine particulate matter (PM2.5) The City of Prince George's Clean Air Bylaw prohibits all open burning, including backyard burning, and land clearing burning. During air quality advisories, this bylaw also prohibits recreational fires, use of wood-burning appliances (except for sole wood burning heat users), and street sweeping activities (unless approved by an Authorized Person). Industry is required to follow permit requirements that are triggered during air quality advisories and are asked to reduce emissions wherever possible. ### People with cardiovascular disease can be particularly sensitive to air pollution. They will generally experience more serious health effects at lower levels. Pollution can aggravate the disease leading to increased medication use, doctor and emergency room visits, and hospital visits. For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-01-16T09:11:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2020-01-15T17:12:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1966899508.2020
Area: Stuart - Nechako, Prince George

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. An intense Pacific frontal system will give snow to the Sea to Sky area. Snow from the system will start this morning and become heavier tonight. Total snow accumulations of 20 to 30 cm can be expected before the snow tapers off to a few flurries on Thursday morning. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-16T05:08:32-00:00
